This is a chess set derived from my glChess chess set, but with many improvements. I have redrawn all the piece profiles by hand and now generate all the pieces in OpenSCAD using rotate_extrude. I have remixed the knight from zheng3's "Garden Guardian", which is an improved version of my original knight (June 23, updated "horse3.stl"; cleaned up a few wayward lines and points, and widened the muzzle so that it looks more like a horse and less like a dragon when viewed from the front). June 26, 2015 update: Added split versions of all the pieces except the rook to avoid overhangs and make the pieces printable without support (the rook has worse overhangs when printed in halves).
All pieces, both the whole and split models, have been widened a bit at the neck so that they are not quite so delicate and prone to snapping in half. Also, removed all the individual DXF and SVG files and collected them into two ZIP files. For an OpenSCAD-designed chess board to go along with the chess set, see http://thingiverse.com/thing:957958

These pieces all have overhangs exceeding 45 degrees and should be printed with support. However, pieces with the filename containing the word "split" have been cut in half to be printed separately, without supports, and glued together. All files are included. If you just want to print, download the scad_*.stl files. If you want to compile from source in OpenSCAD, download all the other files. The profile curves were drawn in xcircuit (profiles.ps) but can be manipulated in inkscape from the SVG files. To print without supports: The rook has an overhang of about 60 degrees. Be cautious of the layer height used and the capabilities of the printer, and the rook can be printed as one piece. The other pieces have been modeled split down the middle, to be printed in two pieces and glued together. Alignment holes are provided, with a diameter that should snugly fit a peg made out of a short piece of filament. The pawn, queen, and king split pieces are symmetric and should be printed twice. The knight and bishop pieces are antisymmetric and each has a version "2" that is flipped relative to the other. Print one of each for a completed piece. The featured photo is a set of pieces I did using eSUN wood filament from http://www.intservo.com. The rook was printed vertically; all other pieces used the split models. Finishing work started with a light sanding to roughen the surface and make it more wood-like. Filament "pegs" were inserted in the split pieces, and the pieces were glued with cyanoacrylate (super glue). The seam between the half-pieces was filled with wood filler. When dry, each piece was thoroughly sanded with fine-grit sandpaper to a smoother finish. This was followed by two coats of stain (MinWax Provincial 211) and a semi-gloss coat. Finally, each piece was rubbed down with fine steel wool.

comments.text: It's a hole-and-peg method.  If you're printing with 1.75mm filament, the holes are designed to fit a short length of the filament right off the spool.  Just grab a spool, jam the end of the filament into the hole, then cut it a few mm above the hole so that it sticks out like a peg.  The peg then not only aids in aligning the two sides, but is also a very strong support for holding them together.

comments.text: That horse was made in OpenSCAD? O_o  wow!
comments.author: mbartels

comments.text: Sorry, no, that would be a little too extraordinary to be true. Fortunately OpenSCAD has an "import STL file" function, which I rely on to pull in anything non-geometric. The horse was designed (mostly) in wings3D. Zheng3 made significant improvements (in what software, I don't know), adding the much nicer mane, flaring the nostrils, and improving the position of the head. Finally, I pulled that back into wings3D and widened the muzzle, repositioned the ears, and cleaned up a few wayward vertices. Then it was ready to import as a complete object into OpenSCAD. The queen's crown could probably be done in OpenSCAD with the right series of cuts, but again, it was easier to import the STL from the previous chess set, with a few minor tweaks in wings3d (mostly subdividing the mesh so the facet boundaries don't show). Everything else in the chess set is done with OpenSCAD primitives.

title: Galaxy Note 3 Bose i20 QC Battery Clip

description.text:
Another of these designs at the request of a user. Derived from my own Galaxy Note 2 Version.  
Clip is shifted to one side so as not to obstruct the camera
Print slowly (~40mm/s) with plenty of shells. Clip thickness is 2.4mm, so is well suited to upto 6 shells with a 0.4mm nozzle.

comments.text:
It just fitted - I suspect that the wireless charger recveiver I have on the battery causes the back cover of the Note to bulge ever so slightly, causing the clip not to fit perfectly. I have no way of moding the model, so I ended up printing it scaled up by 1% and put it in the oven at 100C (I used PLA) and molded it to the phone while the plastic was malleable. This did the trick and it fits really tight.
Thanks!

This is a JR module case for OpenPilot OPLink mini radio. You can install your OPLink inside this box and then use it just like a regular JR transmitter module. I recommend to print the parts with Slic3r pillar support, rotated 90 degrees, so that the models are right way up.  
Plug in USB during flight or install a bluetooth module to a spare port in OPLink for full telemetry awesomeness!  
It comes in 4 versions, straightMMCX is the current model with straight antenna connector. The others are intended for the one with 90 angle, those are the ones that shipped after Kickstarter. The files with logo on them have OpenPilot logo bossed on top of them. Change filament during printing to show off the OP logo!
Install OPLink with antenna pigtail, install bottom to transmitter, make wires from module connectors to OPLink (needs 5v ubec), and screw the top part on. I used DIN7982 2,2x9,5 mm screws.

Otherwise though, even though i was warned that some areas may not come out in the print, the physical parts seemed to have merged fine where there were paper thin edges in the virtual model. In the future I think it'd be great if each block in 3D tin were given a dimension (like 1mm^3) and perhaps even have scaling options (build with 10cm^3 blocks, 1 cm^3 blocks, 1mm^3 blocks, etc). Thanks for making 3D tin, it's a great intuitive program that i got the hang of quite quickly.

I find that even though the units aren't encoded in the STL, i can print things in the size i set in Solidworks. As an estimate i think it would be nice toe have the size of a single cube for input but since now i have a reference i can estimate how big to model things in 3D tin. I guess it would be most beneficial to those using 3D tin for the first time to see how large the object they're making will be
comments.author: jyro

comments.text: There is no unit info in an stl so you have to know what units will be used. In replicatorg 1 unit = 1 mm. So if you made something 2 inches across and sent it to an stl and brought it into repG it would show up as 2 mm. RepG has a nice convert inches to mm button. But knowing that a thing in 3dtin was "x units wide" might help.

title: Roots blower for near field cooling

description.text: For air to be delivered through a tube to a 3D printer nozzle needs more pressure than available from an axial or centrifugal fan, but not as much as would be delivered by a piston or diaphragm pump. This simple Roots blower design works well in this application and is able to deliver 15l/min to a nozzle through 1 meter of 8mm bore silicone tubing.

Instructions are in a PDF file in the source directory  
Edit: Two of the rotors will be needed.

title: Simple handle for aluminium bed on Prusa Mendel I2

description.text:
Simple handle for the print bed of my prusa mendel i2.
I recently needed to replace my bed bearing mounts that had started to crack so, at the same time, I replaced the plywood bed base with a sheet of 3mm aluminium and mounted my heated bed to that. Thought it needed a nice easy to grip handle so designed this in freecad and printed it. It simply slips on to the 3mm thick aluminium and seems tight enough not to need any fixing. Ive included the freecad source as well as the stl.

description.text:
I wanted to add two switches to my Makerbot to turn on/off light and the second heater on my custom heated build platform (first heater is managed by the Extruder Controller). So I designed a simple plate in Sketchup that fits on the side of the Makerbot.
Switches and Led caps have been purchased at Conrad (in Switzerland), I can provide the part numbers if needed

• Print
  • Add switches and Led inside Led caps to the plate
  • Wire everything
  • Attach with printed holders and M3 bolts

description.text:
2-6-2016: added tougher legs, already proven it's worth .. they realy don't break anymore.. just your frame wil, if you hit a lantern post at full speed.. :D ( i did !)
12-11-2015: Added a sleeker TriCopter centerplate. (V2)
11-11-2015: Build a new Mini Racing TriCopter (size:230).
Added 3 new STL files:
  • Tri centerplate;
  • Servo Yaw mount and hinge; ( Turnigy XGD-11MB servo )
  • Motor Yaw Mount.
    For the legs u can use the ones also used for the Quad and Hexa.
    Yaw hinge to servo connection i used a piece of 1mm thick paperclip.
    For the hinge itself use a M4x25 bolt.
    • TriCopter setup:
  • 10A simonk Esc's
  • RCX 1804 2400KV motors
  • APM mini 2.6 flight controller ( http://nl.aliexpress.com/item/High-Quality-Sale-Mini-APM-V3-1-Flight-Controller-For-ArduPilot-Mega-External-Compass-APM-Drop/32471430412.html?ws_ab_test=searchweb201556_3_79_78_77_92_91_80_61,searchweb201644_5,searchweb201560_9 )
  • MiniAP GPS with compass ( http://nl.aliexpress.com/item/New-Ublox-7-Series-Mini-GPS-w-Compass-for-APM2-6-APM2-8-PX4-Pixhawk-Mini/32481950052.html?adminSeq=206058708&shopNumber=342338 )
  • Turnigy XGD-11MB Yaw servo
  • Frsky V8FR-II 2.4Ghz receiver ( without casing and pins ! )
  • Weight without battery : 216 grams
  • TOW with 3S turnigy nano-tech 1500maH : 338 grams
  • Flight time about: 10 minutes
  • No FPV installed yet.
    • 4-8-2015: Added some new files > lighter legs + anti-warp version. new centerplate with more space for cabling, also lighter :) ..
    I've build a new Hexacopter specs below:
  • APM mini controller
  • 10Hz Ublox GPS
  • 10A SimonK ESC's
  • RCX 1804 2400kv motors
  • 5030 GemFan props
  • Turnigy nano-tech 3S 2200 45-90C battery
  • FrSky X4R-SB 16 channel telemetry ACCST receiver
  • Bascom 600mW 5.8Ghz 32ch. mini Video transmitter with Mobius connector
  • Homebrew RGB lighting system
  • and i've used the anti-jello mount from my ZMR 250 frame with a new baseplate incl. in sourcefiles for my Mobius.
  • Weight w/o/ battery: 420 grams
  • Flight time with 2200maH battery > 7 - 7:30 minutes ( with mobius and VTX )
    • https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cFCEnaaKUqY

I wanted to print my own frame for a mini racing fpv quad ....
also included a center plate for a hexacopter ( next project :D )
and here it is ------->

600mW 5.8Ghz video TX

description.text:
Needed a case to keep my KL25Z protected for when I throw it in my backpack.
It looks like the base will fit the KL46Z but I haven't tested it. Link to board: http://www.freescale.com/webapp/sps/site/prod_summary.jsp?code=FRDM-KL25Z

Requires moray's 7.3mm frame spacers from here (framespacer v3.stl): http://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showpost.php?p=29918506&postcount=215 These are used with Turnigy LED strips (7.3mm tall), and perfectly fit 6 LED's, with wires soldered behind. I've used heatshrink where the wires are, just to keep them from banging around during crashes. Much better than the 3-LED version. They are spaced so they fit just inside the outside of the arms, so in the event of a crash they should be protected, unless you hit it that hard that you destroy 2 arms in the process :). I've also uploaded a new version (further in frame version), which puts them 2mm further inside the frame, just so you have even less risk of hitting them in a crash. I only use them on the rear, so chances of actually smashing them on anything is far less anyway :).
Printed at .25mm layer height in ABS, but PLA will work just as fine.

I designed this Arduino DRO (digital readout) housing for my lathe utilizing Yuriy's Toys Android DRO Project (website listed below). Basically, it is a system that utilizes an Arduino connected to scale controller(s) communicating with an Android device via Bluetooth. In the end, it is a a very nice and inexpensive DRO. Instead of cutting and soldering the controller wires directly to the prototyping shield, I added USB mini breakout boards from Adafruit. Multiple covers are included with the files with 0 to 5 mini USB openings. The cover just snaps onto the base with the four retaining nubs. As you may notice from the photos, I used SeeedStudio's Protoshield (RadioShack) and a Bluetooth Transceiver Module from Amazon. If I build additional units, I plan to use Adafruit's EZ-Link shield to simplify and condense the build. I purchased a low-cost ($50 from Amazon) Android tablet as a dedicated touchscreen instead of using my phone. Actual Tablet: DeerBrook 7" Dual Core 1.5GHz Android 4.4 Tablet. Mounts for this tablet included. PDF includes 2D drawings with dimensions. Yuriy's website has lots of great information on how to do this build. It allows for up to 4 axis and a tachometer. All code is free as is the Android application (TouchDRO on Google Play Store).. Certainly worthy of a donation that's available on his site. Great stuff from Yuriy - THANKS! Of course, this could be used for any Arduino UNO (or similar board layout) application where you need a simple mount and cover. Links:
http://www.yuriystoys.com/p/android-dro.html
http://www.adafruit.com/products/1764
http://www.adafruit.com/products/1628 EDIT (12/16/14):
I just realized many "typical" shields will interfere with the original cover design. The top of the cover is more narrow and contacts the shield if shield board is in the same plane as the edge along the USB / power supply side. I have now removed all the original cover files and replaced them with ones that should not not interfere. The SeeedStudio Protoshied I used was "shorter" on the USB / power supply end and did not create a problem. When I tried to use a different shield, I realized the problem. All should be good now. STEP file is now included. EDIT (10/17/16):
Per request, I have uploaded the source Inventor files.

I made this a while ago, but never posted it. I had some time to print a track and vertical loop that I thought might make a cool toy for my daughter to play with. She uses 4 balls of different sizes in the video. Anything like a tennis ball should work. The hard plastic ball didn't work as well as the softer ones. We didn't have any matchbox cars to try out, but those might work too! https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=W7Fc6T-DE1E

This one took a long time to print. 3 of the legs, and 3 of the bases which took several hours each. The loop took the longest and is cut into 3 pieces with 4 connectors pieces total. Glue is helpful if your pieces don't come out perfectly. All were printed on a rep 2 with natural PLA filament.

description.text: Updated part info and replica (printable) original case for self-supplying the parts for the MakerBot Gen4 Interface Kit.

Since my ToM pre-dates the G4IK, I never thought I would want one. But my workflow for printing from the SD card has become increasingly tiresome (especially with Sailfish), so now I want one! Sadly, there's no kit available, so it's time to DIY! First, order a PCB from batchpcb (pcb#79131, thanks to TheMakerGuy's thing:18416). (It's fully possible to protoboard or hand wire, but batchpcb provides a great service.) [2013-07-03] Since thing:18416 is gone, bobc has graciously put up thing:110911 as a replacement. Here are the part numbers and part cost (as of 2013-02-24) from Mouser:
  • 1x 16x4 character LCD (668-NC-S16400XFGSAY; $16.09/ea. There may be other NMTC equivalents for cheaper, but they may not be the right dimensions.)
  • 9x B3F 12x12mm std tactile switch (653-B3F-4055; $0.375/ea).
  • 9x B3F switch keycap, grey (653-B32-1300; $0.25/ea). There are more colors; check the other 13xx parts.
  • 2x 20-pin IDC socket, 3M (517-8920; $1.03/ea).
  • 1x 20-pin IDC header, 3M (517-30320-6002; $0.57/ea)
  • 3ft 20-pin ribbon cable (shielded/rounded: 517-3659/20FT; $1.47/ft. Basic: 517-3365/20FT; $0.38/ft).
  • 2x 5v LED, red (696-SSLLX5093HD-5V; $0.27/ea).
  • 2x 5v LED, green (696-SSLLX5093GD-5V; $0.25/ea).
  • 4x resistor, 1kOhm (291-1K-RC; $0.054/ea).
  • 9x resistor, 10kOhm (291-10K-RC; $0.054/ea).
  • 1x trimpot, 10k 1/4"sq (72-T70YE-10K; $0.80/ea).
  • 2x 8-pin, 8" .100 cable (538-28100-0335; $0.25/ea). two, to make 16-pins!
    Feel free to order larger quantities to "save" on cost; there's bound to be things you can do with 50 resistors, extra buttons, or wire!
    • Hardware parts (from your parts bin, local hardware store, part supplier, amazon, etc):
  • 4x M3 x 16mm socket cap bolt
  • 4x M3 x 22mm socket cap bolt
  • 8x M3 nut
  • 4x M2 x 16mm socket cap bolt
  • 4x M2 nut
    • While you're waiting for shipping & delivery, print the case.
  • The case is designed in OpenSCAD (polygons imported from the original DXF). I've added built-in spacers and hex cutouts (which probably don't save plastic overall, but looks cool).
  • Each part is split into halves (to fit a ToM build), with an extra set of mirrored side STLs. The way the parts have been halved, glue/acetone/cement may not be necessary to keep things together.
  • The front has support pieces built-in so the M3 bolt head is recessed; just snap them out.
  • Otherwise, construction is as per the instructions on makerbot's thingomatic PDF archive page.
    • Notes:
  • You may want to wait until the parts arrive to verify that all the bolt holes fit (especially the LCD).
  • The left-most (X-) button may be tight against the case front; you may need to shave a few microns off the left side of the hole.
  • Since plastic is a good source of static... be careful with the LCD -- there's warnings everywhere about static shock damage.

title: Desktop stand for 5" LCD panel frame

description.text:
Assembly shown with:
  • Backshell for 5" LCD Panel
  • Front Bezel for 5" LCD Panel.
    • The system is altogether made to fit a 5" HDMI LCD panel I got at Adafruit. They list it as a Raspberry Pi accessory. NOTE
    The vertical part needs to be narrowed a little; I forgot to give the customary .25mm for slop. You'll be sanding if you print these as-is. :-)
    NEW
    I added Base_Vert_slim.stl and Base_Vert_tall.stl. Both have slimmed vertical parts so they should insert into the base. The _tall part is an extra cm tall.
    NEW
    /NOTE Note: the screw holes are 50mm centered, square, made to permit a #4 screw, so you can use it to mount a 60mm fan for desktop use, as well.

Print Base_Bot.stl with (Base_Brackt.stl and Base_Vert.stl) or (Base_Vert_Rgd.stl). The three-part print should support a little bit of tilt, requiring some 4-40 screws (or 6-32 for a tight fit). Print it solid, 2-3 shells. Clean it up and check insertion, make sure you have it lined up correctly and apply a little CA adhesive ("super glue") to the underside of the top part, and stick 'em together. Be careful to not let CA squeeze out the bottom or you'll glue it to your worktop. Presently test-printing .2mm, 3 shells, 50% fill, with supports and raft.

The Rocket trains, now equipped with a motor and gear. Have made modifications to the model so it fits this propulsion. Engine and transmission is complete and comes from, Velleman, Gearbox KNS7.
The complete model of the Rocket can be found here.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:564002
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=rlceSEJylaI

Motor part. on the plate sits a fixed wing on each side, It shall be removed. I sanded it down with motor slip. Once that's done solder the wires on the electric motor.
Select ratio 1:60. The long shaft should be cut to 62mm length (Driving wheel axle)
Press down on the bracket, as the pictures show. Select the appropriate battery type. should be put in the barrel to give the locomotive a little weight. install a switch between the battery and motor. And maybe some type of speed control, I noticed that they only fit 3 AA baterier.

author: andrmort

title: Art Deco (sort of...) broom wall hook

description.text:
Wall hook for a broom with a little flair.  The opening diameter of the .STL is 22mm.  To resize use the Customizer feature.  
Enjoy.

I printed this hook on a MakerBot 2X in PLA on kapton. Build plate at 70C, extruder at 205C, 3 shells and 15% fill. I turned on supports for the mounting hole relief cuts on the back of the hook. Customizer Settings: Handle_dia: diameter of the handle of the broom handle, 22 mm in my case
Mount_height: Vertical height of overall part
Wall: Thickness of the walls of the hook, bigger for more weight
Drop: Amount the hook rakes downward toward the wall
Tab_thickness: Thickness of the plate against the wall
Hole_dia: Diameter of mounting holes
Wedge_height: Vertical height of the hook wedge shape
Fn: Number of facets on cylindrical surfaces, more makes rounds smoother.

author: thowe

description.text: This is my name.

This is a tool to tighten the 7/16" nut which holds the amp jack in place on many electric guitars. Tighten with your fingers or use the slot to turn the wrench with a flat head screwdriver. This is also a solution for jacks that have fallen into the guitar body after the nut has loosened and fallen off. You can pull the jack out of the body and hold it in place while re-threading the nut by using a thin wire or hook through the screwdriver slot and down the center of the wrench.
Sketchup, Printrbot Simple, Trial and Error.

This headphone wall mount uses 1/8in screws. The ones in the picture are toggle bolts and can be bought here. http://amzn.to/1w9QdZ3 http://amzn.to/1w9QdZ3 They are a little expensive for screws but they work wonders on drywall. This design requires no support. I printed it with a 30% infill and .3mm layer height. If you have any more questions just ask. Also if you are printing this with a printrbot metal as I did make sure you turn skirt off. I'm not sure why but when it printed with a skirt the printer overstretched and grinded on the gear. If anyone has a solution to this I would love to hear it. I am using CURA.

author: sadsub

description.text:
This is a simple hub for standard 3/8" / 9.5mm clear vinyl hoses to connect to for formicarium setups to increase organization a bit and reduce the amount of hoses needed to connect sections together.  
Tiny grooves are in the base to reduce filament pull distance and warping.

This proved to be simply too much of a hassle to do properly, so no further development will happen. Were it not so, it would probably be moved, along with all my other designs to youmagine, because of Makerbot's blatant disregard of intellectual rights and them stealing from the very same community they emerged from.
https://www.youmagine.com/users/chopmeister
UPDATE 13.2.2014. I am thinking of changing this design to be completely printable, and working on that currently. Stay tuned.
This is an upgrade for the UM, which enables you to get rid of the short belts on your X and Y axis. The original concept was made and developed by snowygrouch, as presented on the Ultimaker forum, the difference being that his design uses printed mounts for the motors, while I am trying to make the thing with lasercut parts. You can find instructions and files for his version here: http://www.calumdouglas.ch so go take a look.
The reason behind this upgrade is to have one less source of potential backlash, and thus more precision.

Take your files off of Thingiverse, and save your designs from being stolen.
http://hackaday.com/2014/05/24/makerbot-files-patents-internet-goes-crazy/
They stole from others, they WILL steal from you.

It was created using Terrain2STL; A web-based service that converts publicly available HGT files to useful STL files

description.text: When you get a makerbot usually everything at home gets broken and needs to be repaired. This is what happened to my pot cover handle. As the cover won't surpase 100ÂºC while cooking because the water maintains this temperature while boiling, it will resist for ages.

In order to get a nice surface in the handle's top, print it in a heated surface as hot as you can without risking the object deformation that usually happens while cooling. i printed mine at 160Âº and this surface looks great. Maybe you have to adjust the hole in order to suit your cover screw.
Screw the piece to the cover when it is still hot, just when coming out of the printer. Since ABS contracts around 2% when cooling, this will help to tight the union and keep the handle in place.

title: Ultimaker Z axis adjuster 4 bed leveling
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: To adjust the bed level better

Print one top and one bottom. (you may want to mirror Z for printimg)
  • Dismount the top Z endstop
  • mount the top with 2 M3x16 screws and 2 M3 nuts from the inside
  • mount the bottom with 2 M3x20 screws from the outside (through the frame) on the switch.
  • take one M3x30mm screw and any spring (eg. from a pencil) and put the top and bottom with the spring and an other nut together.
    • Adjust the Z-Level by turning the vertical screw cw or ccw.

comments.text: Use the spare feeder knurled head screw and extend it with an distance bolt.

remixed_from.author: MarcoAntonini
remixed_from.title: RepRap Touch TFT LCD (mini pronterface style)

description.text:
I wanted to fix the LCD screen to my Huxley in such a way that I could remove and replace it easily. I also needed to power it from the +12V supply from the Sanguinololu board as using the +5V supply was (in my view) causing the 7805 regulator on the Sanguinololu to get too hot - remember that the RRP Huxley is powered from a 19V supply meaning that the 7805 regulator has to dissipate the heat arising from dropping 14V.
My solution to the supply problem was to use a Pololu Step-Down Voltage Regulator - D15V35F5S3. This is a switching regulator and is highly efficient.
My solution to the take off - replace requirement was to use some 10mm x 5mm x 2mm magnets which I had purchased for another project.
The case design uses the following printed parts: LCD Case Clip.2
These are supports for the case once held in place by the magnets. These supports clip around the plastic cable tidy on the Huxley's M6 rod. LCD Case
This is the main case body which has two pockets in the side to accommodate two magnets. LCDCaseBottom
Fits snugly to the back of the case M6 Magnet Carrier
This takes two magnets and attaches to the Huxley frame over the polythene spiral cable tidy between the two supports using M3 screws and nuts to hold it in place Pololu Voltage Reg Carrier
This fits inside the case and connects to the +12V and GND pins on the Sanguinololu and to the +5V and GND pins of the LCD board. Stylus Clip
This fits to the side of the case and takes a Nintendo DS type stylus - I bought a few of these on EBay. As the LCD display is of the resistive type and heavily populated with buttons and controls, I found that a stylus is more accurate than a finger!

Take a look at the photographs to see how the parts are assembled - it isn't that complicated. I have added an STL called LCD Case 3.9 which carries several of the parts listed in the description. Take care when pushing the magnets into their respective pockets as they are a tight fit and not easy to remove. Pay particular attention to the polarity of the magnets - you need to make sure that both of the magnets on the frame of the Huxley in the M6 magnet carrier attract the ones on the side of the LCD case - easy to get this wrong which leads to all sorts of bad words. (I know - I got it wrong :-) ) One thing to note is how I have secured the Pololu voltage regulator which has four holes in it - one at each corner. To keep things simple, the board is held in place by heating up and squashing the four pins on the carrier - not very elegant but it does the job. Make sure all is working before heating up and squashing the plastic pins down though! Code for the RepRapPro Huxley LCD display can be found on Marco's Github as well as my own : https://github.com/Alzibiff/RepRapLcd4D
The code you need is in the Single Extruder directory/folder and will be work in progress - who knows what little extras might be useful in the future?
The button on the bottom right of the display is used as a quick way to populate the Extruder and Heated bed temperatures and toggles between PLA and ABS. The relevant temperatures are held in the CONSTANT.INC file - change these (and other similar constants) to match your needs. I am using this display to make the Huxley totally stand alone - no PC, laptop or USB cable required.

This is a derivation of the R2D2 robot to fit inside some elements provided by the bq robotics kit that allows it to move. By now, its capable to follow a black line, and with an Android app by blueetooth is posible to control remotely to go forward, backward, left, right, turning the head and play sound. You can watch the first steps in this video. As this project was submitted to the "Support-free competition", the stl archives must been downloaded from myminifactory's website (you must register, but it's a nice web with good and tested designs ;)). Please, don't print arduino_holder.stl hosted in thingiverse (yes from myminifactory), because it's not the latest version. The Arduino program and the Android app will be public soon (now it's not very smart ;s).

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Witbox

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2-0.1

Infill:

15%

It can been printed at 0,2 mm height and 15% fill and "support free".
The left foot, right foot, and dome are recomended to print at 0.1 mm height.
The colors can be white outside parts, grey dome, and blue the lens, and inside parts corresponding the color of the robotics kit boxes. It needs to buy an interruptor, a female power jack and an L-type male power jack (the arduino fits too much ;s). For assembly, it needs:
  • 27 u. M3 nuts
  • 10 u. M3x10 bolts
  • 11 u. M3x25 bolts
  • 6 u. M3x40 bolts
    • The software version, such as all the sources, stls... you can download from github [0] [0] https://github.com/j0s3b4/r2d2hs

title: Circular Elements
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Snap-together sockets designed for circular PCBs. I lengthened the default hinge length. This makes for a stronger hinge that is also harder to snap together. It is still compatible with the Breakout Elements hinges. The .stl files provided are examples and probably won't work for any boards you have lying around. The circle diameter is in the filename, except for "lily" which is an untested version that might fit the lilypad arduino. compatible with http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:5822

Circular boards are easy to make using a drill and a hollow drill bit from your local hardware store. With these snap together holders, you can use circular circuit boards to prototype on interesting and aesthetically pleasing surfaces and polyhedra. Radioshack also sells circular protoboard, and some Sparkfun boards like Lilypad (just barely fits) are circular. This script is designed to use 3,4,5, and 6 sided polygons. You must specify the polygon size and the radius of the circular board when you call the module. Other parameters in the module are defaulted to be compatible with thing 5882. Here is what I would do to build a circuit-board buckyball :
-1- pick a style of prototyping board
-2- estimate largest circle diameter for hexagons and pentagons (I measure 45mm for hexagons and 32mm for pentagons)
-3- add a good 7mm(ish) buffer to these estimates to figure out how much board you'll need
-4- find hollowed out drill-bits with an inner diameter no more than a few mm larger than your chosen diameters
-5- using these bits, drill through a piece of wood to make a guide for drilling out the boards
-6- using the wood for guidance, drill out circular prototyping boards : 12 pentagon-sized and 20 hexagon-sized
-7- measure the actual diameter of the boards, and use this script to generate suitable pieces. You may want to adjust the bracket size to give some room for error
-8- print test brackets for hexagons and pentagons and make sure they fit
-9- print 20 hexagons and 12 pentagons and assemble your buckyball shaped prototyping surface

description.text:
Camera slider with stepper motor Edit: Fixed a mistake made on the sledge
Edit 2: Centered the hole in the sledge. Added 7mm to the feet.
Edit 3: Added the SketchUp-files (created in 2015 version) TODO: Add something to fix the belt to on the sledge...

For 8mm rods and LM8UU
  • Print the brackets and two sledges
  • Fettle or drill the 8mm holes.
  • The LM8UU linear bearings is really tight, I did put the sledge (not the whole thing) in boiling water for 10-15 sec and then pressed the bearings into place.
  • Connect the two sledges with two M3 screws

  • Drill a hole for in the center of the sledge and attach a tripod head

  • Optional: add a stepper motor to the motor bracket, a bearing to the other bracket and a belt to automate the slider...

Designed in Metasequioa LE then converted to .stl file via Blender (because nothing is ever straight forward :p) Printed at the Aardvark's makerspace using a Printrbot Simple 1405
Printed on Printrbot 1405 at 20% size with support, 0.3mm Z height and  30% infill using natural PLA (slic3r and repetier doing their thing n_n)

The piece that connects the piston rod to the valve chest near the front of a 1986 New Bright toy train.  The original piece was black with white stripes.  
The model fits the left side of the train; it could be mirrored to fit the right. It should fit into place, but it will need to be glued on the end that connects to the train body.

My second "thing", I built this especially for my potato cannon! I can easily get over 140 yds with just rocks! Just imagine how this will fly!! Note: Keep away from children, aim away from face!
I haven't printed this yet because my printer is delayed another week!!! Its shipping on Monday May 11! I'm thinking of printing this first. If anyone has their MakerBot up and running, I invite you to print this to see how it comes out and leave feedback on it so I can improve further designs.

The stupid CADspan program messed up one of my fins but im sure one can trim the base down to match the bottom of the fin. Or you can use a hot glue gun to fill in the gaps but stick some of your plastic in it instead of hot glue. Scale this up to 50mm (thats the inside diameter of 2" schedule 40 PVC pipe.) If the projectile is too big just sand it down until it fits, snug.

description.text:
An s-hook for my oven handle. The hook stretches to fit around the handle and then cannot fall off by itself.  
The default settings are for a 27 mm diameter handle. Note that the small diameter parameter isn't 27mm -- it needs to be larger to allow for enough space for the handle to fit through the 60 degree opening on the small end. A good rule of thumb is to make the small diameter 30% larger than the handle you will attach it to.

I recently sponsored a Kickstarter project for a Makesmith CNC router. It has some plastic gears that are easily misassembled, so I created some parts to make the gears be easily attached without needing to align them. (they attach to a FS90R servo and a ¼ / 20 threaded rod 7/16" nut). It should be able to adapt easily for other projects as well.
Super glue a nut in the nut gear, and a screw into the servo side. align the rod with the servo and it should couple easily.

Update: For the latest design, please check out: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:904304 This is version 2 of my prosthetic finger designs, which work well for individuals that are missing the last 2 segments of a finger, but still have a short stump. I can provide Sketchup files or export in another format if helpful to anyone. Here it is in motion: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=iSYBMSrvFLY Thanks to the great folks who have been working on 3d printed prosthetics longer than me who gave inspiration and ideas. Please contact me if you need any help on finger prosthetics for yourself or someone in need.

I print the socket with NinjaFlex, and then the parts with PLA.  
The PLA cleanup is pretty standard, be sure that all holes are smooth, and hinges fit cleanly with enough clearance.  In the next revision I'll clean up some of the tolerances a bit.  
I print everything with support, you might be able to get by on some parts without it.  For the socket, a quick pass of the inside with a Dremel sanding drum does wonders to clear that out.  
I use PLA for hinge pins, with caps that put on the ends for a clean look and positive closure.  Just cut some filament a bit longer than you need, melt the end briefly with a lighter / soldering iron, and squish the cap on the end.  
Same elastic as most hand projects use, but I prefer 50lb braided fishing line for the tendon.  
It needs to anchor to the other side of your wrist, so that bending the wrist does not move the finger, only moving the stump does.  For this I use a bracelet which the tendon anchors back to.  
I use a small jewelry clasps (cheap on amazon) to connect the tendon to an aluminum turnbuckle from an RC car, allowing for easy adjustments of tension.  I really like how the turnbuckles work and look, but they are a bit pricey, so in another revision I'll come up with something printable for that part too.

description.text:
NOTE:  Requires Scosche MagicMount Surface (~$10-15 at WalMart, Fry's, etc)  
Designed to clip to the vent of your Mazda3 (tested on 2009 model year).  Works with most smart phones.  Angled 15 degrees towards the driver.  Solid enough you can press iPhone home and power buttons without any movement.

Just print and attach the self-adhering Scosche MagicMount.  
Top of the clip goes over the topmost vent slat; the bottom goes under the lowest.  When clipping to the vent, I've had the best luck clipping the top slat first.  The clip can deflect pretty far if you're using ABS; don't worry too much about breaking it.  
If it slides too easily, add some hot glue to the inner corners of the clip (where it contacts the vent slats; see photo) for additional grip.  Just be sparing; it gets hot enough in the summers here that the glue may remelt and bond to the vent slats.

description.text:
Just a nice model to print.
The files are in 1:5 scale. I divided in printable parts, no support needed, some finishing needed.
I installed in the front plate a 24-8-8mm ball bearing to make the shaft to roll smooth. source files at http://ecatalog.weg.net/drawings_2d_3d/index.asp?empresa=WMO&language=PT&cm=NEMA/W22_GENERAL_PURPOSE/26_FRAME_364_5T/STANDARD&shortcut=&path_relativo=&path_raiz=

This little toy took 12h to build in my prusa.
Most parts are 0.3mm layer, some fine parts are 0.2mm layer Some cleaning and assembly required. Enjoy,
Paulo
